raw_text:
Budget to set scene for election
 
 Gordon Brown will seek to put the economy at the centre of Labour's bid for a third term in power when he delivers his ninth Budget at 1230 GMT. He is expected to stress the importance of continued economic stability, with low unemployment and interest rates. The chancellor is expected to freeze petrol duty and raise the stamp duty threshold from £60,000. But the Conservatives and Lib Dems insist voters face higher taxes and more means-testing under Labour.
 
 Treasury officials have said there will not be a pre-election giveaway, but Mr Brown is thought to have about £2bn to spare.
 
 - Increase in the stamp duty threshold from £60,000 
  - A freeze on petrol duty 
  - An extension of tax credit scheme for poorer families 
  - Possible help for pensioners The stamp duty threshold rise is intended to help first time buyers - a likely theme of all three of the main parties' general election manifestos. Ten years ago, buyers had a much greater chance of avoiding stamp duty, with close to half a million properties, in England and Wales alone, selling for less than £60,000. Since then, average UK property prices have more than doubled while the starting threshold for stamp duty has not increased. Tax credits As a result, the number of properties incurring stamp duty has rocketed as has the government's tax take. The Liberal Democrats unveiled their own proposals to raise the stamp duty threshold to £150,000 in February.
 
 The Tories are also thought likely to propose increased thresholds, with shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin branding stamp duty a "classic Labour stealth tax". The Tories say whatever the chancellor gives away will be clawed back in higher taxes if Labour is returned to power. Shadow Treasury chief secretary George Osborne said: "Everyone who looks at the British economy at the moment says there has been a sharp deterioration in the public finances, that there is a black hole," he said. "If Labour is elected there will be a very substantial tax increase in the Budget after the election, of the order of around £10bn."
 
 But Mr Brown's former advisor Ed Balls, now a parliamentary hopeful, said an examination of Tory plans for the economy showed there would be a £35bn difference in investment by the end of the next parliament between the two main parties. He added: "I don't accept there is any need for any changes to the plans we have set out to meet our spending commitments."
 
 For the Lib Dems David Laws said: "The chancellor will no doubt tell us today how wonderfully the economy is doing," he said. "But a lot of that is built on an increase in personal and consumer debt over the last few years - that makes the economy quite vulnerable potentially if interest rates ever do have to go up in a significant way." SNP leader Alex Salmond said his party would introduce a £2,000 grant for first time buyers, reduce corporation tax and introduce a citizens pension free from means testing. Plaid Cymru's economics spokesman Adam Price said he wanted help to get people on the housing ladder and an increase in the minimum wage to £5.60 an hour.
llama3.2:1b: Gordon Brown is set to deliver his 9th Budget at 1230 GMT, focusing on economic stability and low unemployment.
The Chancellor will freeze petrol duty and raise stamp duty thresholds from £60,000.
He may also extend tax credit schemes for poorer families and provide help for pensioners.
The Conservatives and Lib Dems are pushing for increased taxes, higher means-testing, and more investment in the economy to offset any potential gains made by Labour.
However, Labour's Treasury officials have a significant budget of around £2bn, suggesting they won't be giving away anything without a pre-election giveaway.
llama3.2:3b: Gordon Brown will deliver his ninth Budget with a focus on economic stability, freezing petrol duty and raising the stamp duty threshold from £60,000.
Treasury officials have £2bn to spare, but conservatives claim Labour's pre-election giveaways will be clawed back in higher taxes if they win.
The Lib Dems propose a £150,000 threshold, while the SNP wants a £2,000 grant for first-time buyers and Plaid Cymru seeks an increase in the minimum wage.
gemma2:2b: Gordon Brown will present his ninth budget, aiming to highlight economic stability as a key theme for Labour's re-election campaign.
The chancellor is expected to freeze petrol duty and raise the stamp duty threshold from £60,000.
However, the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats criticize Labour's plan, claiming it leads to higher taxes and means-testing.

While the Treasury plans no pre-election spending sprees, a budget surplus of approximately £2 billion could be allocated for various initiatives like tax credits for low-income families and possible pension assistance.
The Conservative Party proposes increased stamp duty thresholds, while the Liberal Democrats advocate for a threshold as high as £150,000.
A clash of economic visions is predicted with differing projections of investment between Labour and the Conservatives by Ed Balls, David Laws, and George Osborne.
Meanwhile, the SNP favors a first-time buyer grant, reduced corporation tax, and a means-tested pension system.
Plaid Cymru seeks to aid those trying to buy homes and increase the minimum wage.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Budget focuses on economy during election 1230GMT Gordon Brown will focus on economy in his ninth Budget when delivering the first Labour term.
He is expected to raise petrol duty, freeze stamp duty, extend tax credit scheme for poorer families and help pensioners.
Mr Brown hopes to keep voters happy with higher taxes and more means-testing under Labour.
He also said there will not be a pre-election giveaway but he expects around £2bn from the government.

UK property prices have tripled in recent years while average UK property prices remain high so stamp duty is rising as buyers try to avoid it, leading to a rise in tax credits for families and businesses.
The Tories are likely to propose higher taxes with the right to claw back any increase from Labour.

David Laws says the economy will grow after the election but a lot of this growth is built on debt and personal and consumer debt over the last few years which makes it vulnerable if interest rates go up.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Gordon Brown's Budget aims to stress economic stability by freezing petrol duty and raising stamp duty, while Conservatives and Liberal Democrats propose higher taxes and more means-testing under Labour.
Treasury officials expect about £2bn of spare funds for giveaways.
Stamp Duty Threshold Rise: Intended to help first-time buyers; rocketed as average property prices doubled but tax take increased despite unchanged threshold since 10 years ago.

- Prime Minister seeks to emphasize continued economic stability, freeze petrol duty and raise stamp duty threshold
- Conservative and Liberal Democrat proposals suggest higher taxes and more means-testing under Labour
- Treasury officials expect about £2bn of spare funds for giveaways under Labour
- Stamp Duty Threshold Rise: Intended to help first-time buyers; average property prices doubled but tax take increased despite unchanged threshold since 10 years ago
qwen2.5:3b: Gordon Brown will focus his ninth Budget on economic stability, with emphasis on low unemployment, interest rates, and stable petrol duty.
Key points include a stamp duty threshold rise from £60,000 for first-time buyers, extending tax credits for poorer families, and potentially helping pensioners.
Labour's main proposals are criticized by the Conservatives and Lib Dems as likely leading to higher taxes and more means-testing post-election.
The Liberals propose raising the threshold to £150,000; Tories suggest increased thresholds to combat perceived Labour "stealth taxes."
Brown is expected to have about £2bn to invest.
Meanwhile, the SNP and Plaid Cymru offer alternative policies including grants for first-time buyers, reductions in corporate tax, and wage increases.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary is:

* Gordon Brown will seek to put the economy at the centre of Labour's bid for a third term in power when he delivers his ninth Budget at 1230 GMT.
He is expected to stress the importance of continued economic stability, with low unemployment and interest rates.
The chancellor is expected to freeze petrol duty and raise the stamp duty threshold from £60,000.
But the Conservatives and Lib Dems insist voters face higher taxes and more means-testing under Labour.
* Treasury officials have said there will not be a pre-election giveaway, but Mr Brown is thought to have about £2bn to spare.
* Ten years ago, buyers had a much greater chance of avoiding stamp duty, with close to half a million properties selling for less than £60,000.
Since then, average UK property prices have more than doubled while the starting threshold for stamp duty has not increased.
Tax credits As a result, the number of properties incurring stamp duty has rocketed as has the government's tax take.
The Liberal Democrats are also thought likely to propose increased thresholds, with shadow Treasury chief secretary Oliver Letwin branding stamp duty a "classic Labour stealth tax".

* The Tories are also thought likely to propose increased thresholds, with shadow Treasury chief secretary George Osborne saying: "Everyone who looks at the British economy at the moment says there has been a sharp deterioration in the public finances, that there is a black hole."
If Labour is elected, there will be a very substantial tax increase in the Budget after the election.
* For the Lib Dems David Laws said: "The chancellor will no doubt tell us today how wonderfully the economy is doing," he said.

"But a lot of that is built on an increase in personal and consumer debt over the last few years - that makes the economy quite vulnerable potentially if interest rates ever do have to go up in a significant way."
* For the SNP, Alex Salmond said his party would introduce a £2,000 grant for first time buyers, reduce corporation tax and introduce a citizens pension free from means testing.
Plaid Cymru's economics spokesman Adam Price said he wanted help to get people on the housing ladder and an increase in the minimum wage to £5.60 an hour.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Gordon Brown will deliver his ninth budget at 1230 GMT, emphasizing continued economic stability with low unemployment and interest rates.
He aims to freeze petrol duty and raise stamp duty thresholds from £60k to £150k.
Conservatives and Lib Dems suggest voters face higher taxes and more means-testing.

Labour expects a £2bn spare in taxes before the election and plans for a £35bn investment difference under Tory plans, concerned about rising personal debt as a potential vulnerability if interest rates increase.
tinyllama:1.1b: As the latest budget for the upcoming general election draws closer, the Labour Party is expected to announce tax cuts and support for first-time buyers as well as measures to help households facing economic hardship.
However, their proposed tax increases could potentially raise higher taxes and means-testing under Labour, while reducing spending commitments by the main parties' respective manifestos.

The Liberal Democrats have also expressed concerns over the government's budget plans, with former Chancellor Ed Balls suggesting a substantial increase in investment and a £35bn difference between the two main parties' economic projections.
For the Lib Dem party, David Lawson suggested that if the plans remain the same, "the economy is doing very well" and it would be "a bit of an exaggeration to suggest otherwise".
However, for the SNP, Scottish leader Alex Salmond criticized a planned increase in personal and consumer debt and said their policy would introduce £2,000 grants for first-time buyers.
Plaid Cymru's economic speaker Adam Price proposed measures to get people on the housing ladder and a minimum wage hike of £5.60 an hour.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In summary, the UK general election (GE) is scheduled for May 7th-12th, with the key parties' manifestos discussing economic policies.
Amongst these are increasing the stamp duty threshold from £60,000 to £80,000 and a freeze on petrol duty.
This comes as an attempt by Labour to distance itself from the Conservatives and the Lib Dems, who are expected to increase taxes and introduce higher means-testing.
The Conservatives and the Lib Dems are expected to propose alternative policies, such as increased thresholds and a citizens pension for first-time buyers.
phi:2.7b: Gordon Brown is seeking to put the economy at the centre of Labour's bid for a third term by delivering his ninth Budget with low unemployment and interest rates, but no pre-election giveaways.
He will freeze petrol duty and raise the stamp duty threshold from £60,000, but there are expectations that higher taxes and means-testing under Labour could be imposed.
The Conservatives and Lib Dems oppose the increase in the stamp duty threshold for first time buyers as it was a key theme in all three of their general election manifestos.
The tax credit scheme for poorer families is also expected to be extended by Mr Brown, but there is no pre-election giveaway and Treasury officials have said there will not be one.
Labour's manifesto could include help for pensioners as well.
The Conservatives intend to propose increased thresholds with a higher tax take if Labour is returned to power.

The budget has been designed to maintain economic stability while keeping the unemployment rate low, but there are concerns that an increase in personal and consumer debt over the last few years makes the economy vulnerable to potential interest rate hikes.
The Lib Dems have proposed various measures to help first-time buyers get onto the property ladder and reduce corporation tax.
Plaid Cymru is calling for a £2,000 grant for first time buyers, an increase in the minimum wage to £5.60 per hour, and no means testing for their citizens' pension.
orca-mini:3b: Gordon Brown will deliver his ninth Budget at 1230 GMT, with the economy expected to be at the center of Labour's bid for a third term in power.
The chancellor is expected to focus on maintaining low unemployment and interest rates, but there will be no pre-election giveaway.
However, £2bn will be spare for the chancellor to use as he sees fit.
There will be a rise in the stamp duty threshold from £60,000, a freeze on petrol duty, and possible help for pensioners.
The Liberal Democrats are expected to propose increased thresholds, while the Conservatives say their proposals will be clawed back in higher taxes if Labour is returned to power.

Shadow Treasury chief secretary George Osborne said there would be a tax increase of around £10bn in the Budget after the election, and an examination of Tory plans shows a difference of £35bn in investment by the end of the next parliament between the two main parties.
The SNP, Plaid Cymru, and Adam Price all want to introduce a £2,000 grant for first time buyers, reduce corporation tax, and introduce a citizens pension free from means testing.
hermes3:3b: Brown's Budget to focus on stable economy; raises stamp duty threshold, freezes petrol tax, may extend tax credit scheme for poorer families, and potential assistance for pensioners.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: In his ninth Budget, Prime Minister Gordon Brown focused on emphasizing economic stability with low unemployment and interest rates as the centerpiece of Labour's campaign for a third term in power.
The Chancellor is expected to freeze petrol duty and raise the stamp duty threshold from £60,000 in an effort to help first-time buyers.
Although officials have stated there will not be a pre-election giveaway, it is believed that Brown has approximately £2bn to spare.
The Conservative Party proposed increased thresholds as well, with shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin calling stamp duty a "classic Labour stealth tax."

Meanwhile, the Liberal Democrats and SNP (Scottish National Party) presented their own proposals for economic improvements, such as increasing the stamp duty threshold further up to £150,000 or offering a £2,000 grant for first-time buyers.
The Plaid Cymru economics spokesman Adam Price also called for assistance with obtaining housing and an increase in the minimum wage to £5.60 per hour.

Key measures include freezing petrol duty, raising the stamp duty threshold from £60,000, and extending tax credits for poorer families.
The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats argue Labour's policies will lead to higher taxes and more means-testing.
Treasury officials deny a pre-election giveaway, though Brown has around £2bn available.
The opposition criticizes Labour's handling of public finances, with the Tories warning of a £10bn post-election tax increase and the Lib Dems highlighting rising personal debt.
Other parties propose measures such as grants for first-time buyers, corporation tax cuts, and a higher minimum wage.
stablelm2:1.6b: Chancellor Gordon Brown is expected to emphasize the importance of continued economic stability, low unemployment, and interest rates during his ninth Budget, while freezing petrol duty and possibly raising the stamp duty threshold from £100,000 for first-time buyers.
The Conservatives and Liberal Democrats argue that voters will face higher taxes and more means-testing under Labour, despite Brown's reportedly large budget surplus.
Tax credits have led to a rise in properties subject to stamp duty, contributing to the government's tax take.
Both major parties are expected to propose increased thresholds during their election manifestos.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Gordon Brown is set to present his ninth Budget, focusing on maintaining economic stability with low unemployment and interest rates.
Raising the stamp duty threshold from £60,000 to help first-time buyers, aligning with other parties' general election plans.
Extending a tax credit scheme for lower-income families and possibly assisting pensioners.
Potential additional support for first-time buyers.
The Conservatives and Lib Dems anticipate higher taxes and more means-testing under Labour, with the Tories estimating a £10 billion post-election tax increase.
Brown is believed to have around £2 billion left in his budget.
The SNP plans a £2,000 grant for first-time buyers, reduces corporation tax, and offers a citizens pension free from means testing.
Plaid Cymru advocates increasing the minimum wage to £5.60 an hour and assisting first-time buyers with housing.
